bboxes.raw_text:
A four hour sit in by the local
chapter of the Congress of Racial
Equality last week at a West
Washington Street eating place
ended when the owner agreed to
appear before the city council on
behalf of the proposed public &C
commodations ordinance.


Led by Delbert Hodge, Phoe-
nix CORE chairman, more than
a dozen demonstrators refused
to leave John Slatterys coffee
shop located at 43S W. Washing
ton.


Slattery said he would support
the ordinance because 1t would
take the decision TO serve Gus
toners out Of his hands.


When he decided TO serve the
mixed group Of demonstrators,
bartender James Brandon, 80,
704 N. 9th Ave-, threw down his
apron and said he quit,

NEW YORK Students hurled
eggs and insults at former Mis-
sissippi Gov. Ross Barnett when
he appeared on the Harlem Cam
pus Of the City College Of New
York to speak on civil rights.


More than 200 policemen we're
stationed around Shepard Hall
where Barnett spoke. The main
floor Of the auditorium was
TANNED with about 1000 stu
dents.

A five weeks preschool Tor
prospective first graders will
be held In the Roosevelt Dis
trict from July Is . Aug. IA.
Glasses will be free but a small
charge for midmorning snack
about ten cents will be needed.


Seven schools participating In
the program are Valley View. Rio
Vista, Roosevelt. Sheraton Park
Palmdale. Sunland and Sierra
Vista.


Parents may enroll their child
rem in the principal S office OF the
school they choose. Call Br. o.
1881 for further information.
Principals require registration
before June 8.

Pre- School Held
In Roosevelt


School District

SAN FRANCISCO--One of two
Negro jurors in civil rights
trial stood up and shouted, Il
was assassinated and crucified in
the jury room because am a
Negro"


A near riot started after one
spectator hit a court bailiff.


Jurors Geraldine carp and Jo-
sephine Nichols charged after the
Jury had deliberated rs hours
following a two weeks trial Of IA
defendants.


Mrs. carp said she wanted to
be accused because she felt when
she enters the jury room she was
on trial because Of her race.


White jury members said the
Negro women disregarded the
evidence.


Another jury later convicted
IL defendants who we're charged
with trespassing. They were
among the 500 persons arrested
In various demonstrations In the
eifV

Rep. F. A. Higgins. 1915 East
Rancho Drive, announced as a
Republican candidate for a SIX
year term as member Of the
Arizona Corporation Commits
sion The incumbest is A. r.
Buzard, Democrat.


Higgins, So, is completing six
years as a member of the Ari-
IONA House. During his tenure he
has sponsored such legislation as
the narcotics control code and the
law repeating the licensing OF
l4-and-l5 year olds to operate
motor scooters.


Now sales representative for
Phoenix radio station KOY and It's
Arizona network. Higgins began
work here In le43 as the sta
tion's chief engineer. He Is a
member of the Phoenix Adver-
Using Club, a former Maricopa
County chairman for the March
of Dimes and Is member OF
the Phoenix Elks Lodge. During
World War II he worked with the
psychological warfare division
attached toGeneral Eisenhower
supreme allied headquarters In
Europe,

Higgins Seeks
Com mission Post Now

LOS GELES-Loren Miller,
publisher Of the California Eagle,
was appointed a municipal court
judge Tuesday by Gov. Edmund
Brown.


Miller, 81. partner Of the
law firm of Miller and Malone,
started publishing one Of the
states leading Negro newspa-
pers in 1851.


He is we'll known In civil rights
fields and has been active mira
ternal and civic work.

american military railroad
units we're effectively employed
in key overseas areas during


W orld War II. Military railway
battalions of the Army Transpor-
tation Corps operated railroads
during the war in England, French

Morocco. Algeria, Tunisia. ST.
ely. Italy. France. Holland. Bel
GUM, Luxembourg, the Philip
pines. and the Yukon District Of
Canada, among other areas. Fol-
lowing the war they operated
railroads in Japan and Korea.
